title: This year's biggest dividend payers
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Jul 11, 2015, 09:27 BST - UK Markets closed This year's biggest dividend payers By Richard Evans | Telegraph – 27 minutes ago 316.80 +9.30 
Which firms will pay their shareholders more this year and which ones face having to cut their payouts? 
If your income depends on dividends from shares, two questions probably weigh on your mind: which companies are likely to increase their payments to shareholders, and which look destined to cut them? 
Research published this week offers answers to both questions. 
For example, investors who own shares in retailers such as supermarkets should expect their dividend income to fall by 23pc in the current financial year, according to Markit (NasdaqGS: MRKT - news ) , which compiles data on dividends for companies worldwide. 
• Budget 2015: investors face tax raid on dividends 
By contrast, banks should pay 23pc more this year. The sector that accounts for more dividend income than any other, oil and gas, is forecast to offer more modest growth of 5.6pc. 
Here we look in more detail at the dividend prospects for the various sectors. 
= Retailers = 
Dividend growth forecast: 23.2pc 
Income investors in this sector face a tough time. Following this year’s expected fall, Markit predicted a further 15pc cut in 2016. 
Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) will pay no final dividend for 2015, while Markit predicted that Sainsbury’s payout in November would be around 33pc lower than last year, based on its policy of distributing half its “underlying” earnings to shareholders. Wm Morrison is targeting a payment of around 5p for 2016, a fall of 64pc. 
= Banks = 
Dividend growth forecast: +23.2pc 
The banks had to make drastic cuts to payouts during the financial crisis; finally the tide seems to be turning, although some of the large percentage increases simply reflect how little is paid currently. 
Lloyds, for example, should raise its dividend by 30pc when it announces its results for 2015, Markit said. It predicted that the bank would reach its target of paying half its profits to shareholders by 2017, implying “significant” rises in the near term. 
It predicted growth from HSBC and Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) of 2pc and 8pc respectively. 
= Oil and gas = 
Dividend growth forecast: +5.6pc 
Despite the dramatic falls in the oil price (since partially reversed), firms in the sector, which pays more in dividends than any other, are still expected to make modest increases to their payments. 
“The sector accounts for more than 15pc of the total projected payout from large and medium-sized UK stocks,” Markit said. “As such, a dramatic fall in oil prices poses the greatest risk to equity income.” 
But it added that, “while challenges remain”, it expected BP and Royal Dutch Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) to maintain their payments to shareholders this year. 
• Ten shares for dividend growth until 2020 
• Income portfolio: 11 shares that can afford the dividends they pay 
“Management at both companies are aware of the importance of the dividends to shareholders and the impact of any reduction on the investment case,” the firm’s report said. 
The recovery in oil prices from lows reached earlier in the year goes some way to ease the pressure on the oil majors and the relative strength of the dollar is helping to offset the impact of slower growth in payouts across the sector, it added. 
= Drugs and health care = 
Dividend growth forecast: +4pc 
Britain’s two drugs giants, GlaxoSmithKline (Other OTC: GLAXF - news ) and AstraZeneca (NYSE: AZN - news ) , are hugely important to income investors. Both are expected to maintain their dividends rather than raise them. Growth in the sector will come from smaller firms such as Shire (Xetra: S7E.DE - news ) and Smith & Nephew (LSE: SN.L - news ) , Markit said. 
It pointed out that Glaxo offered an attractive yield of 7.2pc but that, based on analysts’ profit forecasts, the firm would be handing 100pc of its earnings to shareholders this year and 80pc in 2018. This “raises some concerns about the sustainability of the dividend”, the report said. 
“We are forecasting a maintained dividend from AstraZeneca,” it added. 
= Personal (LSE: PGH.L - news ) and household Goods = 
Dividend growth forecast: +15.9pc 
This sector includes major dividend payers such as tobacco firms, as well as housebuilders. 
Since 2008 British American Tobacco and Imperial Tobacco (LSE: IMT.L - news ) have delivered steady annual growth of around 11pc in their dividends, Markit said. It predicted increases this year of 3.6pc and 10pc respectively. 
Dividend increases from housebuilders were expected to be 26pc this year and 8pc next.
